instruction:
ENGAGEMENT CONTEXT — populate all fields before running this prompt. These values override anything inferred from prior steps.

Client Name: [CLIENT_NAME]
Engagement Name: [ENGAGEMENT_NAME]
Engagement Code: [ENGAGEMENT_CODE]
Engagement Manager: [ENGAGEMENT_MANAGER]
Partner in Charge: [PARTNER]
Industry Sector: [INDUSTRY]
Service Line / Capability: [SERVICE_LINE]
Delivery Methodology: [WATERFALL / AGILE / HYBRID]
Fee Structure: [FIXED_PRICE / TIME_AND_MATERIALS / CAPPED_T&M]
Engagement Start Date: [START_DATE]
Engagement End Date: [END_DATE]
Total Budget / Fee: [BUDGET]
Primary Workstreams: [WORKSTREAM_1], [WORKSTREAM_2], [WORKSTREAM_3]
Key Client Stakeholders: [NAME (ROLE)], [NAME (ROLE)], [NAME (ROLE)]
Engagement Complexity: [LOW / MEDIUM / HIGH]
Regulatory / Compliance Requirements: [FREE TEXT OR NONE]

---

You are a PwC engagement planning assistant with access to code interpreter.

Refer to the following documents generated in this message thread above:
- Engagement Intake Summary (P1.1)
- Stakeholder Analysis (P1.2)
- Engagement Charter (P1.5)

Before building the Governance Framework, you must first work through a structured governance clarification process with the user. Follow the steps below in sequence.

---

CONTEXT CHECK

Before presenting any clarification questions to the user, count how many of the 16 Engagement Context fields above are populated (i.e. not blank and not containing a placeholder like [CLIENT_NAME]).

If fewer than 8 of the 16 fields are completed, output the following warning and stop — do not proceed to Step 1 until the user confirms the fields are filled:

"⚠️ Insufficient engagement context detected. Only [N] of 16 required context fields are populated. To generate a meaningful Governance Framework rather than a generic template, please fill in at minimum: Client Name, Engagement Name, Delivery Methodology, Fee Structure, Engagement Start Date, Total Budget, and Primary Workstreams. Update the context block above and re-run."

If 8 or more fields are populated, proceed to Step 1 below.

---

STEP 1 — GOVERNANCE REVIEW AND CLARIFICATION

Parse all three input documents and extract the following:
- Engagement team structure and key roles
- Governance bodies referenced in the Engagement Charter
- Stakeholder influence and interest levels
- Engagement objectives, scope and complexity
- Delivery methodology and workstreams
- Reporting requirements referenced in the charter
- Decision making authority levels
- Escalation paths
- Regulatory and compliance obligations
- Any governance-related open items from the charter

Based on this information present the user with a structured governance clarification as follows:

'Before I build the Governance Framework I need to confirm a few governance design decisions. Please review the proposed structure below and provide your input.

**Proposed Governance Structure**

Based on the Engagement Charter and Stakeholder Analysis I am proposing the following governance layers for this engagement:

| Layer | Governance Body | Purpose | Proposed Chair | Proposed Members | Proposed Frequency |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|

Populate this table with appropriate governance bodies inferred from the engagement complexity, stakeholder map and charter. Include as relevant:
- Steering Committee
- Programme Board (if complexity warrants it)
- Working Group(s) by workstream
- Risk and Issues Forum
- Change Control Board
- Technical Design Authority (if technology workstreams are present)
- Quality Review Board (if quality governance is required)

**Governance Design Questions**

1. Do you want to add, remove or modify any of the proposed governance bodies?
2. Are there any existing client governance bodies this engagement needs to connect into or report to?
3. Who has final decision making authority for scope changes?
4. Who has final decision making authority for budget changes?
5. Who has final decision making authority for resource changes?
6. What is the escalation path if a risk or issue cannot be resolved at the working level?
7. Will the Steering Committee have a formal Terms of Reference document?
8. Are there any governance constraints imposed by the client organisation (e.g. existing committee structures, approval thresholds, delegated authority limits)?
9. What is the quorum requirement for the Steering Committee to be able to make binding decisions?
10. How will governance meeting minutes and actions be managed and distributed?
11. Will there be a dedicated Risk and Issues owner separate from the Engagement Manager?
12. Any other governance considerations you would like reflected in the framework?

Type PROCEED against any item you are happy for me to infer from the available information or leave as To be confirmed.'

---

STEP 2 — CONFIRM AND PROCEED

Wait for the user response before proceeding.

Once the user has responded:
- Incorporate all confirmed governance design decisions
- For any item where the user typed PROCEED or left blank infer the most appropriate governance design based on engagement complexity and industry norms
- Note any inferred decisions as assumptions in the framework
- Cross-reference against the charter and flag any contradictions

Then proceed to build the Governance Framework as specified below.

---

STEP 3 — BUILD THE GOVERNANCE FRAMEWORK

Generate the Governance Framework as two outputs:
1. A formatted Word document (.docx) applying PwC formatting standards containing the full Governance Framework narrative and structure
2. A formatted Excel workbook (.xlsx) containing the meeting cadence planner, decision and action log, governance RACI and terms of reference, and change log applying PwC formatting standards

Make both files available for download.

---

PWC FORMATTING STANDARDS FOR WORD

Typography
- Primary font: ITC Charter (body text). If unavailable use Georgia.
- Heading font: Helvetica Neue (headings and labels). If unavailable use Arial.
- Body text size: 10pt
- H1 size: 20pt, bold
- H2 size: 14pt, bold
- H3 size: 11pt, bold
- Line spacing: 1.15
- Paragraph spacing: 6pt after

Colour Palette
- Primary: PwC Orange #D04A02
- Secondary: PwC Red #E2231A
- Dark: PwC Black #2D2D2D
- Light background: #F5F5F5
- Borders and rules: #DDDDDD

Document Structure
- Page headers: document title left, client name and engagement name right, in grey
- Page footers: confidentiality notice left, page number right, in grey
- First page header block: document title, client name, engagement name, prepared by PwC, date, version, status
- Section dividers: full-width horizontal rule in PwC Orange #D04A02
- All section headings in PwC Orange #D04A02
- Confidentiality footer on every page: 'PwC Private and Confidential — prepared for [Client Name] only'

Tables
- Header row background: #D04A02, text white, bold, 9pt
- Alternating row shading: white and #F5F5F5
- Table borders: 0.5pt #DDDDDD
- Cell padding: 4pt

Callout Boxes
- Key governance principles: left border 3pt #D04A02, background #FFF4F0
- Warnings and open items: left border 3pt #E2231A, background #FFF0F0
- Notes and assumptions: left border 3pt #AAAAAA, background #F5F5F5
- Decision authority: left border 3pt #3B82F6, background #EFF6FF

PWC FORMATTING STANDARDS FOR EXCEL

Fonts
- Headings and column headers: Arial, 10pt, bold
- Body text: Arial, 10pt
- Small labels and notes: Arial, 9pt

Colour Palette
- Primary header background: #D04A02, text white, bold
- Secondary header background: #F5F5F5, text #2D2D2D, bold
- Alternating row shading: #FFFFFF and #F9F9F9
- Borders: #DDDDDD, thin
- Open actions: #FFF8E1, text #F57F17
- Overdue actions: #FFEBEE, text #C62828
- Complete actions: #E8F5E9, text #2E7D32
- Decisions pending: #FFF8E1, text #F57F17
- Decisions made: #E8F5E9, text #2E7D32
- Escalated items: #FFEBEE, text #C62828

Workbook Structure
- Tab colour for main sheets: #D04A02
- Tab colour for reference and template sheets: #F5F5F5
- Freeze top two rows on all tabs
- Auto-filter on all data columns
- Column widths set to content
- Footer on every sheet: 'PwC Private and Confidential — prepared for [Client Name] only' left, page number right

---

WORD DOCUMENT STRUCTURE

**DOCUMENT HEADER (first page only)**
- Document title: Governance Framework
- Client name and engagement name
- Prepared by: PwC
- Date: today's date
- Version: 1.0
- Status: Draft
- Confidentiality notice

**TABLE OF CONTENTS**

**1. Purpose**
A brief section explaining:
- The purpose of the Governance Framework
- How it defines the structures, processes and responsibilities that will govern the engagement
- How it connects to the Engagement Charter
- How it will be maintained throughout the engagement lifecycle

**2. Governance Principles**
A set of 5-8 governance principles that will guide decision making and behaviour throughout the engagement. Present in a key callout box.

Principles should be inferred from the engagement context and should cover:
- Accountability and ownership
- Transparency and communication
- Escalation and issue resolution
- Decision making speed and empowerment
- Stakeholder inclusion
- Risk management
- Quality and standards

**3. Governance Structure Overview**
A narrative description of the overall governance structure including:
- The governance layers and how they connect
- The relationship between PwC and client governance
- How the engagement governance connects to any existing client governance bodies

Follow with a governance structure diagram described in table form showing the hierarchy of governance bodies from top to bottom with connecting relationships.

**4. Governance Bodies**
For each governance body provide a detailed section containing:

4.x [Governance Body Name]
- Purpose and mandate
- Membership table: Role | Name | Organisation | Voting Rights
- Chair
- Meeting frequency
- Meeting format (in-person, virtual, hybrid)
- Quorum requirements
- Decision making authority
- Agenda standing items
- Inputs required
- Outputs and decisions
- Escalation path from this body
- Minutes and actions owner

For each governance body include a Terms of Reference summary box.

**5. Decision Making Framework**
Three sub-sections:

5.1 Decision Making Principles
A narrative describing how decisions will be made, documented and communicated.

5.2 Decision Authority Matrix
A table defining decision making authority across all key decision types:
- Decision Type | Description | Authority Level | Approver | Escalation Path | Timeframe for Decision

Decision types to include:
- Scope change (minor)
- Scope change (major)
- Budget change (within contingency)
- Budget change (exceeding contingency)
- Resource addition or substitution
- Deliverable sign-off
- Risk acceptance
- Issue escalation
- Contract amendment
- Engagement suspension or termination

5.3 Decision Log Reference
A note explaining that all decisions will be logged in the Decision & Action Log (Excel workbook Sheet 2) and that the log will be reviewed at each governance meeting.

**6. Escalation Framework**
Three sub-sections:

6.1 Escalation Principles
A narrative describing when and how escalation should occur.

6.2 Escalation Path
A table showing the escalation ladder:
- Level | Body or Role | Trigger Conditions | Timeframe | Resolution Authority

6.3 Escalation Categories
A table defining what types of issues, risks and decisions trigger escalation at each level.

**7. Reporting and Communication Governance**
A summary of governance reporting requirements:

7.1 Reporting Cadence
A table: Report Type | Audience | Frequency | Owner | Format | Distribution

Report types to include:
- Weekly Status Report
- Fortnightly Steering Committee Pack
- Monthly Programme Dashboard
- Risk and Issues Report
- Financial Report
- Change Control Report
- Milestone Completion Report

7.2 Meeting Governance
A table of all recurring governance meetings:
- Meeting | Purpose | Chair | Attendees | Frequency | Duration | Agenda Owner | Minutes Owner

7.3 Document Management
A brief section on how engagement documents will be stored, version controlled and distributed.

**8. Risk and Issue Governance**
A brief section describing:
- How risks and issues will be governed within this framework
- The role of each governance body in risk and issue management
- Escalation thresholds for risks and issues
- Reference to the Risk Register (P2.7) and Issue & Dependency Log (P2.8)

**9. Change Control Governance**
A brief section describing:
- How change requests will be governed within this framework
- The role of the Change Control Board
- Decision authority thresholds for change approval
- Reference to the Change Control Plan (P2.12)

**10. Quality Governance**
A brief section describing:
- How quality will be governed within this framework
- Deliverable review and sign-off processes
- Reference to the Quality Plan (P2.11)

**11. Governance Framework Maintenance**
A short section describing:
- How the framework will be reviewed and updated
- Who is responsible for maintaining it
- Version control process

**12. Open Items**
A table of any governance design decisions that remain To be confirmed:
- # | Open Item | Priority | Action Required | Owner | Due Date

**APPENDIX A — Document Version History**
Version history table: Version | Date | Author | Summary of Changes

**APPENDIX B — Reference Documents**
List of reference documents: Document | Step | Version | Date | Owner

---

WORKBOOK RATIONALISATION — generate a maximum of 4 sheets:
1. Meeting Cadence Planner — all governance meetings with frequency, next date, chair, agenda owner, and standing agenda items; kept as is.
2. Decision & Action Log — merge the Decision Log and Action Tracker onto one sheet; use a bold section header row to separate decisions (top half) from actions (lower half). Keep all columns from both original sheets.
3. Governance RACI & Terms of Reference — merge the Governance RACI and Terms of Reference Templates; RACI matrix at the top, pre-populated ToR template blocks below with a clear section header for each governance body.
4. Change Log.
Do not generate separate Reference/Definitions or archive sheets.

EXCEL WORKBOOK STRUCTURE

The workbook contains 4 sheets.

**Sheet 1: Meeting Cadence Planner**

Summary bar (rows 1-2):
- Total Governance Meetings per Month: =COUNTIF(E4:E1000,"Monthly")+COUNTIFS(E4:E1000,"Fortnightly")*2+COUNTIFS(E4:E1000,"Weekly")*4
- Meetings This Week: =COUNTIFS(G4:G1000,"<="&TODAY()+7,G4:G1000,">="&TODAY())
- Overdue Meeting Actions: linked from Sheet 2

Columns:
- Meeting ID (="MTG-"&TEXT(ROW()-3,"000"))
- Governance Body
- Meeting Type (dropdown: Steering Committee, Programme Board, Working Group, Risk Forum, Change Control Board, Technical Design Authority, Quality Review, Other)
- Purpose
- Frequency (dropdown: Weekly, Fortnightly, Monthly, Ad Hoc, One-off)
- Duration (dropdown: 30 min, 1 hour, 90 min, 2 hours, Half day, Full day)
- Next Scheduled Date
- Recurring Day (dropdown: Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday)
- Chair
- Agenda Owner
- Minutes Owner
- Attendees
- Standing Agenda Items
- Notes

Conditional formatting:
- Next Scheduled Date within 3 days: #FFF8E1, text #F57F17
- Next Scheduled Date overdue: #FFEBEE, text #C62828

**Sheet 2: Decision & Action Log**

This sheet merges the Decision Log and Action Tracker into one sheet. A section divider row separates the two sections.

DECISION LOG SECTION

Summary bar (rows 1-2):
- Total Decisions: =COUNTA(B4:B500)
- Pending Decisions: =COUNTIF(J4:J500,"Pending")
- Decisions Made This Month: =COUNTIFS(I4:I500,">="&DATE(YEAR(TODAY()),MONTH(TODAY()),1),J4:J500,"Approved")
- Escalated Decisions: =COUNTIF(J4:J500,"Escalated")

Columns (rows 4 onwards, up to row 500):
- Decision ID (="DEC-"&TEXT(ROW()-3,"000"))
- Date Raised
- Decision Title
- Description
- Decision Type (dropdown: Scope Change, Budget Change, Resource Change, Deliverable Sign-off, Risk Acceptance, Issue Escalation, Contract Amendment, Other)
- Raised By
- Governance Body
- Options Considered
- Decision Date
- Decision (dropdown: Approved, Rejected, Deferred, Escalated, Pending)
- Decision Made By
- Rationale
- Impact
- Actions Arising
- Action Owner
- Action Due Date
- Notes

Conditional formatting:
- Decision Pending: #FFF8E1, text #F57F17
- Decision Escalated: #FFEBEE, text #C62828
- Decision Approved: #E8F5E9, text #2E7D32
- Decision Rejected: #F5F5F5, text #AAAAAA

SECTION DIVIDER ROW (row 501): full-width orange header row labelled 'ACTION TRACKER'

ACTION TRACKER SECTION

Summary bar (rows 502-503):
- Total Actions: =COUNTA(B505:B2000)
- Open Actions: =COUNTIF(H505:H2000,"Open")
- Overdue Actions: =COUNTIFS(G505:G2000,"<"&TODAY(),H505:H2000,"<>Complete")
- Due This Week: =COUNTIFS(G505:G2000,"<="&TODAY()+7,G505:G2000,">="&TODAY(),H505:H2000,"<>Complete")
- Complete Actions: =COUNTIF(H505:H2000,"Complete")
- Completion Rate: =IFERROR(COUNTIF(H505:H2000,"Complete")/COUNTA(B505:B2000),0) — format as percentage

Columns (rows 505 onwards):
- Action ID (="ACT-"&TEXT(ROW()-504,"000"))
- Date Raised
- Source (dropdown: Steering Committee, Programme Board, Working Group, Risk Forum, Change Control Board, Other)
- Meeting ID (reference to Sheet 1)
- Action Description
- Owner
- Due Date
- Status (dropdown: Open, In Progress, Complete, Deferred, Cancelled)
- Priority (dropdown: Critical, High, Medium, Low)
- Completion Date
- Outcome
- Notes

Conditional formatting:
- Status Open and Due Date < today: #FFEBEE, text #C62828, bold
- Status Open and Due Date within 3 days: #FFF8E1, text #F57F17
- Status Complete: #E8F5E9, text #2E7D32
- Priority Critical: bold

**Sheet 3: Governance RACI & ToR**

This sheet merges the Governance RACI and Terms of Reference Templates. The RACI matrix occupies the top half; ToR templates are below with clear section headers.

GOVERNANCE RACI SECTION

A RACI matrix mapping governance responsibilities across all key governance activities:

Rows (governance activities):
- Prepare Steering Committee pack
- Chair Steering Committee
- Record and distribute Steering Committee minutes
- Maintain Decision & Action Log
- Maintain Risk Register
- Maintain Issue Log
- Prepare and submit Change Requests
- Review and approve Change Requests
- Prepare Weekly Status Report
- Prepare Monthly Programme Dashboard
- Maintain Engagement Charter
- Maintain Governance Framework
- Manage stakeholder communications
- Escalate risks and issues
- Sign off deliverables

Columns: One column per key role identified in the engagement team from the charter.

RACE values: R (Responsible), A (Accountable), C (Consulted), I (Informed)

Conditional formatting:
- R: background #FFF4F0, text #D04A02, bold
- A: background #FFEBEE, text #C62828, bold
- C: background #FFF8E1, text #F57F17
- I: background #F5F5F5, text #AAAAAA

SECTION DIVIDER ROW: full-width orange header row labelled 'TERMS OF REFERENCE TEMPLATES'

TERMS OF REFERENCE SECTION

A structured template for each governance body identified in the framework. For each body provide a pre-populated Terms of Reference block containing:
- Governance Body Name
- Version and Date
- Purpose and Mandate
- Membership and Roles
- Meeting Frequency and Format
- Quorum Requirements
- Decision Making Authority
- Standing Agenda Template
- Inputs Required
- Outputs and Decisions
- Escalation Path
- Review Frequency

Format each ToR block with orange header rows and clear section dividers.

**Sheet 4: Change Log**

Columns:
- Change ID (="CHG-"&TEXT(ROW()-3,"000"))
- Date
- Sheet Changed
- Record ID
- Field Changed
- Previous Value
- New Value
- Changed By
- Reason for Change

---

DATA POPULATION

Populate all sheets with governance data confirmed in Steps 1 and 2.

For the Meeting Cadence Planner:
- Create a row for each governance body identified
- Set Next Scheduled Date based on engagement start date where known
- Pre-populate Standing Agenda Items for each meeting type

For the Decision & Action Log:
- Decision Log section: Leave blank — ready for use during the engagement
- Add a placeholder row with instructions: 'Log all governance decisions here as they are made. Do not delete this row until the first real decision has been recorded.'
- Action Tracker section: Pre-populate with any open actions arising from the Engagement Charter open items
- Set Priority based on the priority of the originating open item

For the Governance RACI & ToR:
- Pre-populate RACI with role names from the engagement team
- Assign RACI values based on standard PwC engagement governance norms
- Leave cells blank where the role has not yet been confirmed
- Pre-populate each ToR with the governance body details confirmed in Step 2
- Leave member names as placeholders where not yet confirmed

---

Where a field cannot be determined leave the cell blank and add a comment: 'To be confirmed.'

Ensure all dropdown validations are applied and functional.

Ensure all formulas are applied to all data rows and will extend correctly when new rows are added.

Ensure the Governance RACI has exactly one A per row.

Once both files are generated and available for download confirm you are ready to proceed to Step P2.1 Work Breakdown Structure.
